BTC$BTC  aNUPL Shows Elevated Profit, But Without Classic Euphoria  The adjusted Net Unrealized Profit/Loss (aNUPL) provides a clearer view of market psychology by filtering out long-dormant coins and focusing on economically active supply. Historically, major cycle tops tend to coincide with aNUPL pushing deep into the Euphoria/Greed zone, reflecting widespread unrealized gains and speculative excess.

üìâ Why BTC$BTC  Still Controls the Crypto Industry   Crypto firms remain tightly linked to BTC$BTC  price moves, says Michael Novogratz. Even diversified companies can‚Äôt escape market cycles yet.   When Bitcoin drops 30%, revenues often fall the same. Asset management, staking, and trading income are still priced directly off crypto valuations.   Key Points:  ‚Ä¢ Revenue link: lower prices mean lower fees and activity   ‚Ä¢ Industry gap: unlike TradFi, crypto lacks stable income streams   ‚Ä¢ Buffer attempt: data centers and infrastructure reduce volatility   üèó Galaxy‚Äôs infrastructure business is now rivaling crypto ops in value, but a full decoupling may take years. Takeaway: For now, BTC price still sets the tone. Real independence comes only when revenues diversify.  #BTC Price Analysis#  #Macro Insights#   #Bitcoin Price Prediction: What is Bitcoins next move?#

$BTC IS TARGETING THE 89,000 ZONE AFTER A HEALTHY PULLBACKüî•üíØ


Bitcoin is currently stabilizing around the 87,700 area after facing a sharp rejection from the upper 88,800‚Äì89,200 supply zone. The recent move shows a clear impulse followed by a corrective leg, which is a normal behavior in a broader bullish structure. Price respected the lower support near 87,400‚Äì87,600, where buyers stepped in and prevented a deeper breakdown. This reaction suggests that demand is still active at these levels, and as long as BTC holds above this support band, a recovery toward the previous highs remains a valid scenario.


From a long trade perspective, this zone can be considered a potential accumulation area with confirmation. If Bitcoin continues to build higher lows above 87,400 and reclaims 88,200‚Äì88,400, momentum can expand again toward 89,000 and possibly higher. However, failure to hold the current base would weaken the bullish structure. On the short trade side, the rejection from the 89k region highlights strong selling pressure, meaning any weak bounce into 88,800‚Äì89,200 could again attract sellers for a continuation move back toward 87,000 and below.


Short Outlook:
Market is in a short-term consolidation phase after rejection. Holding above 87,400 favors a bounce, while a breakdown below this level may extend downside pressure toward lower supports.

Bitcoin just printed a sharp pullback after an explosive expansion move, and context matters here.  Price is reacting around a major high-timeframe supply zone after a vertical push. The long upper wicks show clear rejection at higher levels, suggesting aggressive profit-taking rather than trend failure. This looks more like a cooldown phase than a full reversal.  From a structure perspective, BTC is still holding well above its prior breakout zone. As long as price continues to hold above that reclaimed range, the broader uptrend remains intact. A period of consolidation or sideways compression here would actually be constructive and allow momentum to reset.  The volume profile shows heavy acceptance much lower, meaning there‚Äôs strong historical participation below current price. That reduces downside risk unless we lose key support decisively.  Big picture: Momentum cooled, not broken. Volatility is expected, but the higher-timeframe trend still favors continuation as long as support holds.  Patience here matters. This is where markets shake out weak hands before the next decision move.

$BTC Common Mistakes Made by Beginner Crypto Traders
Many beginner traders tend to repeat the same mistake: when they see the market dropping, they immediately open short positions, assuming the decline will continue.
However, in many cases these corrections mainly serve to attract more short positions, before a sharp rebound occurs that liquidates them. In other words, opening a short position during a down-move significantly increases the risk of losses.
This is exactly what happened yesterday: many traders entered shorts too late, convinced the market would continue falling ‚Äî and they were liquidated when the rebound arrived.


The current market is highly volatile and often driven by liquidity traps. This is not an environment for impulsive or emotional trading. Without a clear strategy and proper risk management, the likelihood of substantial losses remains very high.

This conversation explores the final footprints and enduring mysteries of Bitcoin‚Äôs creator, Satoshi Nakamoto, and his earliest collaborator, Hal Finney.
Key Milestones
 * Hal Finney‚Äôs Passing: Hal Finney, the first person to receive a Bitcoin transaction, died on August 28, 2014, from ALS. His role in the early days was so pivotal that many still speculate he was Satoshi, though he denied it until his death.
 * The Final Departure: Satoshi‚Äôs last public technical post was on December 12, 2010, regarding DoS security. His final private communication was in April 2011, where he told developers he had "moved on to other things."
The 2014 "Reappearances"
After years of silence, Satoshi‚Äôs accounts became active during the Newsweek controversy:
 * "I am not Dorian Nakamoto": In March 2014, Satoshi‚Äôs P2P Foundation account posted this single sentence to deny that Dorian Nakamoto was the creator.
 * The 2014 Hack: Later that year, Satoshi‚Äôs GMX email was compromised. A hacker used the account to post warnings/threats, leading the community to disregard any non-cryptographically signed messages from that era.
The "Nour" Mystery (2018)
In November 2018, the P2P Foundation account posted the word "nour" (Arabic/Hebrew for "light") and added a Brazilian user as a friend. Because the linked email had been previously hacked, this is widely considered a hoax rather than a return of the real creator.
The Genesis Coins
 * The 1.1 Million BTC: Satoshi is estimated to own over a million Bitcoin. These coins have not moved since 2010.
 * The Genesis Block: The original 50 BTC reward from the first block (Jan 3, 2009) is permanently unspendable due to a quirk in the original code.
 * Recent Activity: While Satoshi‚Äôs coins remain still, 2024 and 2025 saw several "Satoshi-era" wallets (from 2009/2010) wake up and move billions in BTC, though none have been linked to Satoshi‚Äôs specific mining pattern.

$BTC Happy New Year with our best wishes to you and your loved ones!

Bitcoin (BTCUSD) closed the year with a feat that it has historically never done before. And that's closing a year in red (losses) within a Bull Cycle.

So far, the traditional technical pattern was that after a Bear Cycle, BTC posted at least 3 straight green years. The last, post-Halving year was always green (gains).

That held up until yesterday with a red yearly (12-month) candle after two bullish ones in 2023 and 2024. Could that be the end of the traditional 4-year Cycle Theory? Well we don't believe that quite yet. As long as the market makes a new All Time High (or at least Cycle High in the decades that will follow market maturity and mass adoption) on year 4, then the 4-year Cycle Theory should remain the dominant pattern.

Nevertheless, that was a historic first for Bitcoin and we couldn't be more excited on what the future holds! Happy New Year again everybody!

So does the fact that 2025 closed in losses worry you? Feel free to let us know in the comments section below!

$BTC I will now explain what would happen if each nation backed their currency with Bitcoin. 
Inflation: Historically, many fiat currencies (money not backed by a physical commodity like gold) have lost significant purchasing power over time.
‚ÄãHistorical Precedent: Throughout history, dozens of currencies have failed due to hyperinflation (e.g., the Weimar Republic, Zimbabwe, or modern Venezuela), effectively reaching a value of zero.
‚ÄãIntrinsic Value: In a strict sense, a piece of paper (or a digital entry) has no "intrinsic" use like food or fuel. Its value is derived entirely from trust and government mandate. If every nation backed their currency with Bitcoin, it would create a global "Bitcoin Standard," effectively modernizing the old Gold Standard for the digital age. This would be a radical shift from our current fiat system, where governments can print money as needed.
‚ÄãHere is what that world would likely look like:
‚ÄãThe Death of "Infinite Printing"
‚ÄãCurrently, central banks use monetary policy to manage the economy (e.g., printing money during a recession). With a Bitcoin backing:
‚ÄãHard Supply Cap: Governments could only issue as much local currency as they have Bitcoin to back it.
‚ÄãNo Inflationary "Stimulus": Governments could no longer "print their way out" of debt. This would force extreme fiscal discipline but could also lead to deeper recessions because the government loses its "safety valve" to inject cash into the system. Unlike the US Dollar, which loses value over time, Bitcoin is designed to increase in purchasing power because of its scarcity (21 million cap).
‚ÄãPsychology of Spending: If your money is worth more tomorrow than it is today, you are less likely to spend it. While this encourages saving, it can slow down "GDP growth" because the economy relies on constant consumption.
‚ÄãLower Prices: Over decades, the prices of goods would likely trend downward as technology makes production more efficient while the money supply remains fixed. üåéüêÇ

üìà Market Overview

2/9

Senate hearings on the CLARITY Act kick off in January to settle SEC/CFTC turf wars, designate Bitcoin and Ether as commodities, and unlock institutional flows. SEC launches a safe harbor the same month, ending regulation by enforcement. California mandates licensing for digital asset firms by July 1, CFTC finalizes tokenized collateral rules in August, and the GENIUS Act sets federal stablecoin reserve standards by mid-July. Congress faces its biggest test yet on delivering crypto clarity after years of delays.

3/9
üáπüá≤ Turkmenistan

Turkmenistan flips the switch on crypto exchanges and mining operations on Jan. 1, formally legalizing digital asset businesses. 4/9
üá∏üá¨ Singapore

MAS readies draft stablecoin legislation requiring full reserves and redemption rights, aiming to regulate issuance and boost payments adoption. 5/9
üá≠üá∞ Hong Kong

Hong Kong enforces Basel crypto capital rules for banks Jan. 1, giving favorable treatment to certain stablecoins and codifying exposures. HKMA and SFC roll out stablecoin issuer licenses plus expanded VA dealer and custodian regimes early in the year, broadening market access while tightening compliance. The fight with Singapore for Asia's crypto crown enters a decisive phase.

6/9
üá®üá≥ China

China flips digital yuan wallets into interest-bearing accounts on Jan. 1, making the e-CNY competitive with bank deposits as the PBoC doubles down on CBDC adoption and pushes back against crypto. Commercial banks can now pay interest on verified balances, shifting the e-CNY from payment tool to deposit-like instrument. The state-controlled digital currency play gets its most aggressive feature yet.

7/9
üá∑üá∫ Russia

Russia enacts a unified crypto framework July 1, licensing exchanges and depositories while banning privacy coins and capping retail exposure. Bank of Russia unifies regulations for investments and transactions, with enforcement ramping up in 2027 using banking-style penalties. The Kremlin tightens its grip on digital assets while legitimizing state-approved markets.

BITCOIN HAS BROKEN THE TRADITIONAL 4-YEAR CYCLE FOR THE FIRST TIME IN 14 YEARS.

For the first time in Bitcoin‚Äôs history, the post-halving year has closed in red.

In past cycles, the pattern was consistent:

- Halving year usually closes green
- The year after the halving has historically been even stronger
- Then a cycle top and a deep bear market

This time looks different.

2024 (halving year) closed strong. 2025, instead of continuing higher, closed in red. 

That breaks a 14-year pattern.

But this doesn‚Äôt automatically mean Bitcoin is weak. What‚Äôs changed is what drives Bitcoin now.

Earlier cycles were dominated by:

- Halving supply shocks
- Retail speculation

Today, Bitcoin moves more with:

- Liquidity conditions
- Interest rates
- Institutional flows
- Broader business cycles

The halving still matters, but its impact is smaller. In 2012, daily supply dropped by thousands of BTC. In 2024, the reduction was only a few hundred.

So instead of a clean 4-year rhythm, Bitcoin appears to be shifting into a liquidity driven cycle.

The cycle may not be broken, It may simply be maturing.
